snippet: The sixth version of the firm’s plan for a public stock offering contains signs buried in its 1,000-plus pages that should encourage prospective investors.
lead_paragraph: Apollo Global Management’s I.P.O. plans have aged well. Last week, Apollo, Leon D. Black’s buyout shop, filed the sixth iteration of its prospectus, three years after the first. The latest version contains signs buried in its 1,000-plus pages that should encourage prospective investors. Apollo looks ready to move from the dark corners of a private Goldman Sachs exchange, where it trades at a steep discount, to the public market’s bright lights.

headline.main: Promise for Apollo in New Prospectus
